author: Robert Pursell
title: After storms, 2 California ski resorts report snowiest month in history
text:
After storms, 2 California ski resorts report snowiest month in history 
January 23, 2017 
RELATED: Snow emergency declared in Lake Tahoe area 
Currently, Mammoth Mountain and Squaw Valley Alpine Meadows are reporting that January is the snowiest month in either resort’s history. 
On Saturday, Squaw Valley stated on Instagram that they had received over 212 inches of snow in January, breaking a 45-year-old record, while Mammoth on Sunday reported that they had surpassed their old record of 209 inches: A photo posted by Squaw Valley | Alpine Meadows (@squawalpine) on Jan 20, 2017 at 10:20am PST A photo posted by Mammoth Mountain (@mammothmountain) on Jan 22, 2017 at 6:31am PST 
Both Mammoth and Squaw Valley broke their records in the midst of an atmospheric river storm system that is still dumping snow on California’s Eastern Sierra. 
While resorts in the state are still scrambling to dig themselves out from the latest storm (Mammoth got another 2-4 feet in the past 24 hours) it’s possible that once more snow totals are measured, other resorts in California will be reporting a record-breaking month. 
This is all music to the ears of skiers and snowboarders in California, which has been crippled by drought conditions for much of the past five years. As recently as 2014-2015, Squaw Alpine reported a total of 223 inches for the season , a total they’re already coming close to hitting three weeks into January. 
Put into a national context, California has seen so much snow this January that — according to OnTheSnow — of the 15 resorts with the highest snow totals in the United States, 11 of them are in California. Mammoth Mountain, which has the largest snow total in the country, has received fresh snow 15 of the 23 days of this month . 
And all of that snow has excited powderhounds posting photos on Instagram to document the madness: A photo posted by Chris Benchetler (@chrisbenchetler) on Jan 23, 2017 at 7:52am PST A photo posted by Homewood Mountain Resort (@skihomewood) on Jan 23, 2017 at 10:09am PST A photo posted by @jakemarin_ on Jan 23, 2017 at 10:03am PST A photo posted by Mammoth Mountain (@mammothmountain) on Jan 21, 2017 at 6:09am PST
